sections.title: One Person Company
sections.text: Prior to the implementation of the Companies Act of 2013 only two people could form a company. The Companies Act of 2013 supports the formation of One Person Company (OPC) in India. It governs the registration and functioning of one person company in India. In comparison with a public company a private company should have at least two directors and two members however on the contrary, one person company registration doesn't need any group of people to be incorporated.

As per the Section 262 of Companies Act of 2013 and official registration of OPC in India is legal. One person company registration in India requires a single director and a single member representing the whole firm. This corporation type has very few compliance requirements in comparison with a private corporation.

sections.title: Documents Required for OPC Company Registration
sections.heading: A scanned replica of a current bank statement
sections.text: You can access bank statements online through internet banking or by visiting a bank location. Account statements and transaction summary statements are other names for them that are frequently used.

sections.heading: An electricity or gas bill, a phone bill, and a mobile bill
sections.text: Utilities costs typically cover electricity, gas, water/sewage, and rubbish disposal. Since they are now considered ordinary in the majority of Indian households, other services like internet, cable TV, and phone services are occasionally regarded as extra utilities. The price of utilities can vary widely, largely depending on your region, the temperature where you live, and your usage patterns. Hence these are also submitted as important documents for registration of OPC.

sections.heading: Rental agreement in English transcribed in a digital format
sections.text: Rental agreements are usually handed over as hard copies to the tenants. This has to be scanned and provided to the authority for documentation.

sections.heading: A landowner's no-objection certificate transcribed in a digital format
sections.text: This document is from the landowner of the specific land. Every company must always maintain a registered address for the corporation under Section 12 of The Companies Act, 2013 When a business is incorporated in India, the registered address is provided as an attachment to the Spice+ form. However, if the business's address changes after incorporation, a Form INC-22 notification of the new registration address of the company must be submitted to the ROC.

sections.heading: A property or sale deeds scanned copy in English language (if the property is owned)
sections.text: A sale deed is a legal document used in real estate transactions to prove the purchase and transfer of property ownership from the seller to the buyer. This is the primary ownership transfer paperwork. A sale deed is sometimes known as the conveyance deed or the final deed.

sections.heading: Easy Succession
sections.text: Despite having a single person running all the daily activities of the company, OPC provides options for perpetual succession. After the demise of a member of the company, the nominee can run the company.

sections.heading: Limited Liability
sections.text: The member in a one-person company has limited liability. Since OPC is a registered company it is treated as a separate legal entity providing greater protection to its members. The liability of the member is limited to their shares so they are not liable for any losses conducted in the company. In case of bankruptcy, the creditors can sue the company and not the director of the company for procuring the company's debt.

sections.heading: Sole Directorship and Shareholder
sections.text: In one person company registration a single member acts as a director so they stand liable for managing the company's day-to-day activities. In this case, there is no need for an executive director to run the daily needs. A single member is more than sufficient and acts as a shareholder with all responsibilities.

sections.heading: Ownership in Property
sections.text: Since the OPC is treated as a separate legal entity the person has the right to hold property related to business and other assets in their name. The properties including machinery factories, residential property, buildings, and other assets cannot be claimed by another person. As per law, the one person company registration can acquire property directly under its name.

sections.title: Compliances for a One Person Company
sections.text: Certain compliances are outlined in the Companies Act of 2013 and must be met by the specified deadlines. These regulations provide openness, good governance, and safeguard the interests of all parties involved, including the ROC, shareholders, directors, investors, and tax authorities. These compliances can be divided into annual compliances, recurring compliances, post-incorporation one-time compliances, and compliances dependent on events. The first category of one-time compliances has been thoroughly covered here.

sections.heading: One Time Compliance
sections.text: A one person company must immediately comply with specific legal requirements outlined by the Companies Act of 2013 and, if necessary, secure local registrations in accordance with the state laws of the location where the OPC is conducting business. sections.title: Restrictions on One Person Company
sections.text: Despite having major advantages, one person company registration also comes with a certain set of restrictions.

sections.heading: Not Apt for Scalability
sections.text: Registering your business as an OPC is a perfect option for a small business structure. However, if you are planning to scale it up on greater levels then this might not work.at any given time the total number of people in an OPC is always one. If you are planning to add more members and have more shareholders you cannot register your business as OPC. So OPC registration is not apt to raise further capital. This will inhibit the expansion and growth of businesses.

sections.heading: Higher Restrictions on Business Activities
sections.text: As per the rules and regulations, OPC is not permitted to conduct non-banking financial investment activities. Registering yourself as an OPC will not provide freedom to invest in the security of other corporations.

sections.heading: No Clear Distinction Between Ownership and Management
sections.text: Since the one-person company has a single person to act as both the director of the company and the management there is no clear distinction between both roles. A single person is permitted to take and approve all the decisions. So, there are higher chances of unethical practices.

sections.title: Advantages Of OPC Company in India
sections.heading: Legal Standing
sections.text: The member grants the OPC registration a separate legal entity status. The sole person who incorporated the OPC is protected by its distinct legal status. The member is not personally liable for the company's loss; instead, his or her liability is limited to the value of the shares that he or she owns. Therefore, the OPC and not the member or director may be sued by the creditors.

sections.heading: Easy Access to Funding
sections.text: One person company registration in India can easily raise money through venture capital, angel investors, incubators, and other sources because it is a private company. Getting money is now simple.

sections.heading: Less Conformity
sections.text: One person company registration is given some exemptions from compliance requirements under the Companies Act of 2013. The OPC is not required to prepare the cash flow statement. The secretary of the company is not required to provide any annual reports and maintain any account books.

sections.heading: Easy Integration
sections.text: And one person company in India can be easily integrated without any legal hassles. A member also serving as a director should provide the approval for integration. There is no minimum paid up capital requirement.

sections.heading: Easy to Manage
sections.text: Administration of the OPC can be made simple by allowing a single person to both find and lead it. Making decisions is straightforward, and it happens quickly. The member can easily pass both ordinary and special resolutions by writing them down in the minutes book and getting just one other member to sign them. Because there won't be any internal disputes or delays, managing the company will be easy.

sections.heading: Constant Repetition
sections.text: The OPC has the function of perpetual succession even with only one member. A nominee must be chosen by the single-member when incorporating the OPC. The candidate will take over operation of the company in the event that a member passes away.

items.question: What is a one person company?
items.answer: A one person company (OPC) is a type of company structure introduced in India that allows a single individual to establish and manage a company with limited liability. It provides a separate legal entity status to the individual and protects their personal assets.

items.question: What are the features of a one person company?
items.answer: The key features of an OPC include having only one shareholder, limited liability protection, the ability to appoint a nominee, exemption from holding annual general meetings, and relaxed compliance requirements compared to other company types.

items.question: What is the difference between OPC vs LLP vs Pvt Ltd?
items.answer: OPC is a company structure for a single individual, while LLP (Limited Liability Partnership) and Pvt Ltd (Private Limited Company) require at least two partners/shareholders. OPC has limited liability with a separate legal entity, LLP has partners with limited liability, and Pvt Ltd has shareholders with limited liability.

items.question: Who is eligible for OPC?
items.answer: Only Indian residents who are natural persons and not minors can form an OPC. A person can be a member in only one OPC at a time and cannot incorporate more than one OPC.

items.question: What are the documents required for OPC company registration?
items.answer: Documents required for One person company registration include PAN card, Aadhaar card, identity proof, address proof, and passport-sized photographs of the proposed director/member. Additionally, address proof of the registered office and a No-Objection Certificate (NOC) from the property owner may be needed.

items.question: Is OPC public or private?
items.answer: An OPC is a private company by default, as it has only one shareholder. It cannot issue shares to the public, and the word â€˜Privateâ€™ must be mentioned in its name.

items.question: What are the rules for an OPC company?
items.answer: OPCs must comply with the rules and regulations under the Companies Act, 2013, and other applicable laws. They should have a minimum of one director and one nominee, and the nominee's consent must be obtained. OPCs also have certain restrictions on their operations and cannot carry out non-banking financial investment activities.

items.question: What is the OPC registration fee?
items.answer: The OPC registration fee varies based on the authorised capital of the company. As of 2021, the fee ranges from â‚¹ 2,000 to â‚¹ 10,000 for different capital slabs. Check the latest regulations with our professionals.

items.question: Can OPC have directors?
items.answer: Yes, an OPC must have a minimum of one director. The director can also be the sole shareholder/member of the OPC. However, there is no maximum limit on the number of directors, subject to the provisions of the Companies Act of 2013.

items.question: How to register an OPC company in India?
items.answer: To register an OPC, one must follow the process of obtaining a Digital Signature Certificate (DSC) for the director, obtaining Director Identification Number (DIN), obtaining name approval, preparing the incorporation documents, and filing the incorporation form along with the required fees with the Registrar of Companies (ROC).

items.question: What is the tax rate for OPC?
items.answer: The tax rate for an OPC is the same as for other private limited companies. As of 2021, the corporate tax rate is 25% for companies with an annual turnover up to â‚¹400 crores. However, it's essential to consider the latest tax laws and consult a tax professional.

items.question: Can a one person company issue shares?
items.answer: No, an OPC cannot issue shares to the public as it is a private company with only one shareholder. The shareholding remains with the sole member, and any transfer of shares must be done within the framework of the Companies Act, 2013 and the OPC's Articles of Association.

items.question: Can an OPC open a trading account?
items.answer: Yes, an OPC can open a trading account to engage in buying and selling securities in the stock market. The OPC must comply with the necessary regulations and procedures of the respective stock exchange and appoint a designated authorised person for trading activities.

items.question: Can an OPC open a Demat account?
items.answer: Yes, an OPC can open a Demat account. A demat account is required to hold and trade securities in an electronic form. The OPC company needs to approach a depository participant (DP) and complete the account opening process as per the regulations of the depository and stock exchanges.

items.question: What function does a nominee perform in a One Person Company?
items.answer: A nominee is a person who joins the business in the event that the promoter passes away or is rendered incapable.

items.question: How much is the permitted capital fee?
items.answer: The total number of shares that a company may issue to its shareholders is known as its authorised capital. A Company must pay the authorities an issued capital fee before issuing shares.

items.question: What does it cost to maintain a One Person Company?
items.answer: Slightly less money is spent on an OPC than on a private limited company. You'll spend about â‚¹12,000 to incorporate, followed by about â‚¹15,000 per year in compliance fees and the cost of an auditor to review your financial records.

items.question: What exactly is a dead company?
items.answer: If the annual compliances are not met, the company becomes dormant and can eventually be struck off. It takes upto 20 years to be revived.

items.question: What is a DSC?
items.answer: While submitting the document online, the online digital signature certificate electronically confirms the sender's or signer's identity. Some of the application documents must be signed by the directors using their digital signatures, as per the MCA.

items.question: Can I launch multiple OPCs at once?
items.answer: No, a person can only form one OPC at once. In an OPC, the nominee is also covered by this rule.

items.question: What tax benefits are available to an OPC?
items.answer: There are no general benefits, but some benefits that are industry-specific. In addition to the minimum alternative tax and dividend distribution tax, profits are subject to a flat tax of 30%.

items.question: What is the difference between a one person company and sole proprietorship company?
items.answer: Even though both an OPC and a sole proprietorship have only one person or member, they operate in very different ways. OPC is treated as a company with limited liability and the ability to own assets and property. A sole proprietorship, on the other hand, lacks these characteristics. As a result, there is no perpetual succession in the business, and the sole proprietor bears infinite responsibility.

items.question: What Is a Dormant Company?
items.answer: If the annual compliances are not met, the company remains dormant and can eventually be struck off. Up to 20 years can pass before a struck firm can be restored.
